dpipe.split package¶

Submodules¶

dpipe.split.base module¶

dpipe.split.base.get_cv_11(dataset: dpipe.dataset.base.Dataset, *, n_splits)[source]¶
dpipe.split.base.get_cv_111(dataset: dpipe.dataset.base.Dataset, *, val_size, n_splits)[source]¶
dpipe.split.base.get_group_cv_111(dataset: dpipe.dataset.base.Dataset, *, val_size, n_splits)[source]¶
dpipe.split.base.get_groups(dataset: dpipe.dataset.base.Dataset, groups_property='groups')[source]¶

Returns a list which will be used to perform a group-based CV split

dpipe.split.base.get_loo_cv(dataset: dpipe.dataset.base.Dataset, *, val_size=None)[source]¶

Leave one group out CV. Validation subset will be selected randomly

dpipe.split.base.get_subj_ids(dataset: dpipe.dataset.base.Dataset)[source]¶

Returns a list of subject IDs

dpipe.split.base.indices_to_subj_ids(splits, subj_ids)[source]¶

Converts split indices to subject IDs

dpipe.split.base.kfold_split(subj_ids, n_splits, groups=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Perform kfold (or group kfold) split Returns indices: [[train_0, val_0], ..., [train_k, val_k]]

dpipe.split.base.split_train(splits, val_size, groups=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Add additional splits of train subsets to output of kfold Returns indices: [[train_0, val_0, test_0], ..., [train_k, val_k, test_k]]

dpipe.split.cv_111.group_cv_111(dataset: dpipe.dataset.base.Dataset, *, val_size, n_splits)[source]¶
In order to use this splitter, your Dataset needs to have
a ‘groups’ property.

a ‘groups’ property.

dpipe.split.monte_carlo module¶

dpipe.split.monte_carlo.monte_carlo(dataset: dpipe.dataset.base.Dataset, *, train_fraction, val_fraction, n_splits)[source]¶

Example: train_fraction = 0.8, val_fraction = 0.1, n_splits = 2 will create 2 splits such that 80% of ids are in the train sample, 10% - in val sample, 10% - in test sample.
